results.title: More Small Companies Avoid I.P.O.s, Sapping U.S. Economy’s Vitality
results.byline: By ERIN GRIFFITH and MATT PHILLIPS

multimedia.caption: Bill McDermott, the chief executive of SAP, in sunglasses, and Ryan Smith, the chief executive of Qualtrics, rang the closing bell in November at the New York Stock Exchange. Qualtrics agreed to sell itself to SAP rather than go through with a planned initial public offering.

Bill McDermott, the chief executive of SAP, in sunglasses, and Ryan Smith, the chief executive of Qualtrics, rang the closing bell in November at the New York Stock Exchange. Qualtrics agreed to sell itself to SAP rather than go through with a planned initial public offering.

Bill McDermott, the chief executive of SAP, in sunglasses, and Ryan Smith, the chief executive of Qualtrics, rang the closing bell in November at the New York Stock Exchange. Qualtrics agreed to sell itself to SAP rather than go through with a planned initial public offering.

results.abstract: Small and midsize firms are increasingly steering clear of going public, giving big companies outsize influence over stock markets and hampering business creation, wage growth and productivity.

results.title: A Hot Seat for Facebook, an Empty Chair for Zuckerberg and a Vow to Share Secret Files

multimedia.caption: A chair and the name plate for Facebook chief executive Mark Zuckerberg who was invited to give evidence, and declined the invitation, to the Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Committee investigation into disinformation and fake news at the Houses of Parliament in London on November 27, 2018.

results.title: How to Survive the Next Era of Tech (Slow Down and Be Mindful)
results.abstract: In his final State of the Art column, Farhad Manjoo reflects on the industry’s changes and presents a new guide for navigating the future of technology.

results.title: New Zealand Blocks Huawei, in Blow to Chinese Telecom Giant

multimedia.caption: New Zealand rejected a proposal to use technology from Huawei, the Chinese telecom giant, to build its next-generation mobile data network, citing “significant national security risks.”

results.abstract: The announcement came a day after Papua New Guinea said it would uphold a deal with Huawei, illustrating the growing global divide over the risks of Chinese technology.

results.abstract: The colossal museum built by Myanmar’s military to honor itself and its leader showcases the mind-set of a force obsessed with its reputation. A critic calls it “a sign of their megalomania.”

results.abstract: Definers, an import from Washington to Silicon Valley, thrived with opposition research and a fishy campaign to push Apple’s C.E.O. for president.

results.byline: By ERIN GRIFFITH and MATT PHILLIPS

multimedia.caption: Bill McDermott, the chief executive of SAP, in sunglasses, and Ryan Smith, the chief executive of Qualtrics, rang the closing bell in November at the New York Stock Exchange. Qualtrics agreed to sell itself to SAP rather than go through with a planned initial public offering.

results.abstract: Small and midsize firms are increasingly steering clear of going public, giving big companies outsize influence over stock markets and hampering business creation, wage growth and productivity.
